title: Kurtosis of a Normal distribution
text:
The kurtosis of a Normal distribution, say \(X\), is 3. This is given by \[COK = \frac{\mu_4}{\sigma_X^4}= \frac{\mu_4}{(Var(X))^2}\] with \(\mu_4=\mu'_4-4\mu_3'\mu_X+6\mu_2'(\mu_X)^2-3(\mu_X)^4\) and \(Var(X)=E[X^2]-(E[X])^2\).
The package moments in R can be used to calculate the kurtosis of a Normal distribution. If this is done multiple times on a different data set generated from a Normal distribution with mean \(\mu_X\) and variance \(\sigma_X^2\), one can see that it converges to 3. Below a function named kurt_norm is created to implement this. The kurtosis at each iteration are shown in Figure 1.

library(moments)

kurt_norm = function(N = 100,n = 1000,mu = 0,sigma = 1){
  # N     : number of iterations
  # n     : sample size for the generated random values from N(mu,sigma)
  # mu    : mean of the normal distribution
  # sigma : variance of the normal distribution
  x_kurtosis = c()
  for (i in 1:N) {
    x_norm = rnorm(n)
    x_kurtosis[i] = kurtosis(x_norm)
  }
  return(x_kurtosis)
}
res = kurt_norm(N = 100,n = 1000,mu = 0,sigma = 1)
plot(res,type = "o",ylab = "Kurtosis",pch = 16,xlab = "Iteration")
abline(h = 3,col = "red",lwd = 2)
